questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for converting the glycogen molecule from a branched structure to a linear structure during glycogenolysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Debranching Enzyme

Explanation:

 

Debranching Enzymes play a crucial role in glycogenolysis by removing the branches from the glycogen molecule.

 

It has two activities: it transfers a short segment of glucose from a branch to a nearby chain and hydrolyzes the remaining glucose unit at the branch point, thus converting branched glycogen into a more linear form that can be further degraded.

  • Transferase Activity: Moves a segment of 3 glucose units from the branch to the main chain
  • α-1,6-Glucosidase Activity: Hydrolyzes the remaining α-1,6-glycosidic bond at the branch point
    ↓

Free Glucose (from the α-1,6-glycosidic bond)

 

Glycogen Phosphorylase (Option A)catalyzes the cleavage of glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate units by adding a phosphate group. It acts on the linear chains of glycogen, not the branches, and does not convert branched structures into linear ones.

 

Branching Enzyme(Option B) is involved in the synthesis of glycogen, specifically in the creation of branch points by transferring a segment of the glycogen chain to a new location. It is not involved in converting branched structures into linear structures during glycogenolysis.

 

Glycogen Synthase(Option D) is responsible for the synthesis of glycogen from glucose-1-phosphate by forming α-1,4-glycosidic bonds. It is involved in building glycogen rather than breaking it down and does not affect the branched structure of glycogen.

questions.text: Which glycogen storage disease does not involve hypoglycemia or exercise intolerance?
questions.solution:
Andersen’s Disease (GSD Type IV) does not involve hypoglycemia or exercise intolerance. It is caused by a branching enzyme deficiency, leading to abnormal glycogen accumulation in the liver and other organs, eventually causing cirrhosis.

Andersen’s Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV)

Aspect Details
Enzyme Deficiency Branching enzyme (glycogen branching enzyme)
Affected Gene GBE1
Mode of Inheritance Autosomal recessive
Key Features Hepatosplenomegaly, cirrhosis, failure to thrive
Hypoglycemia Absent (Unlike Von Gierke or Cori disease)
Exercise Intolerance Absent (Unlike McArdle or Tarui disease)
Prognosis Progressive liver disease, leading to liver failure

Glycogen Storage Diseases (GSD) Classification

GSD Type Name Enzyme Deficiency Affected Gene Key Features Hypoglycemia Exercise Intolerance
GSD I Von Gierke Disease (Option A ruled out) Glucose-6-phosphatase G6PC Severe hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia Yes No
GSD II Pompe Disease Lysosomal acid maltase (α1,4-glucosidase) GAA Cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, early death (infantile form) No Yes
GSD III Cori Disease (Forbes Disease) Debranching enzyme AGL Mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, muscle weakness, limit dextrin accumulation Yes Yes
GSD IV Andersen Disease Branching enzyme GBE1 Hepatosplenomegaly, cirrhosis, no hypoglycemia or exercise intolerance No No
GSD V McArdle Disease (Option B ruled out) Muscle glycogen phosphorylase PYGM Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria No Yes
GSD VI Hers Disease Liver glycogen phosphorylase PYGL Mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly Yes No
GSD VII Tarui Disease (Option D ruled out) Muscle phosphofructokinase-1 PFKM Exercise intolerance, hemolysis No Yes
GSD IX Phosphorylase kinase deficiency Phosphorylase kinase PHKA1, PHKB, PHKG2 Hepatomegaly, mild hypoglycemia, muscle weakness (some subtypes) Yes Yes
GSD XI Fanconi-Bickel Syndrome GLUT2 transporter defect SLC2A2 Hepatorenal dysfunction, growth retardation, glucose/galactose intolerance Yes No
GSD 0 Glycogen Synthase Deficiency Glycogen synthase GYS1, GYS2 Ketotic hypoglycemia, postprandial hyperglycemia, no glycogen storage Yes No

Classification Based on Hypoglycemia and Exercise Intolerance

  • GSD with Hypoglycemia: Von Gierke (I), Cori (III), Hers (VI), GSD IX, Fanconi-Bickel (XI), GSD 0
  • GSD with Exercise Intolerance: Pompe (II), McArdle (V), Tarui (VII), Cori (III), GSD IX
  • GSD with Both: Cori (III), GSD IX
  • GSD with Neither: Andersen (IV)

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia and elevated ketone levels. Genetic testing was done and diagnosed as Type 0 Glycogen storage disorder. Which of the following statements about Glycogen Storage Disease Type 0 is true?

choices.text: The enzyme deficiency is glycogen synthase.
The affected genes are GYS2 and GYS1.
It is an autosomal recessive disorder

questions.solution:
Glycogen Storage Disease Type 0 (GSD 0) is caused by a deficiency of glycogen synthase, which leads to low glycogen storage in the liver and muscles. It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the GYS1 (muscle glycogen synthase) and GYS2 (liver glycogen synthase) genes.

  • Enzyme Deficiency: Glycogen synthase deficiency leads to impaired glycogen synthesis, causing fasting hypoglycemia and ketosis.
  • Affected Genes: GYS2 affects the liver, and GYS1 affects muscle function.
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive pattern.

Glycogen Storage Disease Type 0 (GSD 0)

Feature Details
Cause Glycogen synthase deficiency (caused by GYS1 or GYS2 mutation)- an autosomal recessive disorder. (Options A, B & C)
Pathophysiology Inability to synthesize glycogen → Reduced glycogen stores → Fasting hypoglycemia and ketosis
Clinical Features Fasting hypoglycemia, ketosis, postprandial hyperglycemia, muscle weakness (GYS1 mutation)
Diagnosis Genetic testing (GYS1, GYS2 mutation), blood glucose and ketone levels
Management Frequent meals, cornstarch supplementation, avoiding fasting

questions.text: A 1 year old child presents with failure to thrive, weak bones, and renal dysfunction. The physician suspected glycogen storage disorder and further identified a mutation in the SLC2A2 gene while genetic testing. Which among the following defects is associated with it?
questions.solution:
The child presents with failure to thrive, weak bones (osteopenia), and renal dysfunction, which are characteristic features of Fanconi-Bickel Syndrome (Glycogen Storage Disease Type XI).

  • Gene involved: SLC2A2 mutation
  • Defective protein: GLUT2 transporter (responsible for glucose and galactose transport in the liver, kidney, pancreas, and intestines)
  • Key features:
    • Glycogen accumulation in the liver and kidney
    • Glucose and galactose intolerance
    • Renal Fanconi syndrome (proximal renal tubular dysfunction leading to loss of phosphate, amino acids, and glucose in urine)
    • Rickets/osteopenia due to phosphate loss.

Fanconi-Bickel Syndrome (Glycogen storage disease Type XI)

Feature Details
Cause Mutation in SLC2A2 gene leading to defective GLUT2 transporter
Affected Organs Liver, kidney, intestines, pancreas
Pathophysiology Impaired glucose transport → Hepatic glycogen accumulation → Renal Fanconi syndrome
Clinical Features Failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, renal dysfunction, osteopenia, hypophosphatemic rickets, fasting hypoglycemia
Diagnosis Genetic testing (SLC2A2 mutation), urine analysis (glycosuria, phosphaturia, aminoaciduria), fasting blood glucose
Management Supportive care, frequent small meals, vitamin D and phosphate supplementation, uncooked cornstarch to prevent fasting hypoglycemia

Liver phosphorylase (Option B): Incorrect because Hers' disease (GSD VI) is caused by liver phosphorylase deficiency, leading to mild hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, not renal dysfunction.

Muscle and erythrocyte phosphofructokinase 1 (Option C): Incorrect because Tarui disease (GSD VII) is due to PFKM gene mutation, causing exercise intolerance and hemolysis, not liver and renal dysfunction.

Muscle Phosphorylase (Option D): Incorrect because McArdle disease (GSD V) is due to PYGM gene mutation, leading to exercise-induced muscle cramps and myoglobinuria, with no hepatic or renal involvement.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with muscle hypotonia and heart failure. Laboratory tests reveal an accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pompe Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type II) is caused by a deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase (α-1,4 and α-1-6 glucosidase), leading to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Infantile-onset form presents with muscle hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), cardiomegaly, and heart failure.
    • Death occurs early due to cardiorespiratory failure if untreated.
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Accumulation of glycogen within lysosomes, confirmed on muscle biopsy.
    • Elevated creatine kinase (CK), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and transaminases and lactate levels.

Pompe’s Disease (Glycogen storage disease Type II)

Enzyme Deficiency

Lysosomal α-1-4 and α-1-6 glucosidase (acid maltase)

Affected Gene

GAA

Clinical Features
  • Muscle hypotonia, death due to heart failure within 2 years of age (seen in juvenile)
  • Muscle dystrophy (seen in adults)

Mode of Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Management
  • Supportive care
  • Enzyme replacement therapy
  • Chest x-ray at regular intervals
  • Obtain an initial echocardiogram to evaluate the extent of cardiomyopathy
  • Medical management may be useful based on the stage of cardiomyopathy.
  • Avoid drastic changes in fluid status, either through dehydration or fluid overload.

Glycogen Storage Disorders 

Disorder Enzyme Deficiency Key Clinical Features
Pompe Disease (GSD II) Lysosomal acid maltase Hypotonia, cardiomegaly, glycogen in lysosomes

McArdle Disease (GSD V) (Option A ruled out)

 Muscle phosphorylase Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria

Von Gierke Disease (GSD I) (Option C ruled out)

 Glucose-6-phosphatase Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis
Cori Disease (GSD III) (Option D ruled out) Debranching enzyme Hepatomegaly, muscle weakness, limit dextrin accumulation

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with muscle weakness and mild hepatomegaly. On physical examination, the child has mild cardiomegaly. Blood tests reveal mild hypoglycemia and elevated serum creatine kinase levels. Which enzyme deficiency is associated with this glycogen storage disease?
questions.solution:
Cori disease is caused by a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to the accumulation of branched glycogen (limit dextrin), hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and muscle weakness.

Cori’s Disease (Glycogen storage disease Type III)

 

Enzyme Deficiency

Liver and muscle debranching enzyme

Affected Gene

AGL

Mode of Inheritance

Autosomal Recessive Inheritance

Clinical Features
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hepatomegaly seen at infancy
  • Limit dextrin accumulation
  • Muscle weakness

Management

  • Dietary Management: A diet high in protein and low in carbohydrates is often recommended to manage the disease.
  • Enzyme Replacement Therapy: In some cases, enzyme replacement therapy may be used to supplement the deficient enzyme.

Glycogen synthase (Option A): This enzyme is involved in glycogen synthesis, and its deficiency causes a Type 0 glycogen storage disease and it does not present with hepatomegaly or cardiomegaly

Glucose-6-phosphatase (Option B): This enzyme deficiency is associated with von Gierke disease (Type I Glycogen Storage Disease) does not present with muscle weakness

Muscle phosphorylase (Option D): Deficiency in this enzyme causes McArdle disease (Type V Glycogen Storage Disease), and it does not present with hepatomegaly or hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with severe hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, irritability, and lethargy between feedings. Laboratory tests reveal elevated lactate, triglycerides, and uric acid. The child frequently feeds to manage hypoglycemia. Based on these findings, which condition is most likely responsible for the symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Von Gierke's Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I) is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, impairing glycogen breakdown and gluconeogenesis.
  • The key clinical features in this infant, such as severe hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, irritability, and lethargy between feedings, strongly suggest impaired glucose release from the liver.
  • Laboratory findings of elevated lactate, triglycerides, and uric acid further support Von Gierke’s disease due to defective glucose metabolism.
  • Frequent feedings are characteristic, as affected infants need continuous glucose intake to prevent hypoglycemia.

Von Gierke's Disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I)

Cause

Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme

Pathophysiology

Inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate to glucose; leads to accumulation of glycogen, lactate, and triglycerides

Symptoms
  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Hepatomegaly and Renomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hyperuricemia and Hyperlipidemia

Diagnosis
  • Biochemical tests (hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia)
  • Genetic testing

Management
  • Frequent feedings with slow-release carbohydrates
  • Blood glucose monitoring
  • Medications for associated conditions
  • Liver transplantation (in severe cases)

Glycogen Storage Disorders (GSDs)

GSD Type Name Enzyme Deficiency Affected Organs Key Features
Type I Von Gierke's Disease Glucose-6-phosphatase Liver, Kidney Severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia
Type V McArdle's Disease (Option B ruled out) Muscle phosphorylase Skeletal Muscle Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, myoglobinuria after exertion
Type VII Tarui's Disease (Option C ruled out) Muscle phosphofructokinase Muscle, RBCs Exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, hemolytic anemia
Type VI Hers' Disease (Option D ruled out) Liver phosphorylase Liver Hepatomegaly, mild hypoglycemia, milder symptoms than Von Gierke's

 McArdle's Disease (Option B): Incorrect because it primarily affects muscle, leading to exercise intolerance and myoglobinuria rather than hypoglycemia.

Tarui's Disease (Option C): Incorrect because it affects muscle and red blood cells, leading to exercise intolerance and hemolytic anemia, not hypoglycemia.

Hers' Disease (Option D): Incorrect because it causes mild hypoglycemia without lactic acidosis, whereas this case presents with severe hypoglycemia and metabolic abnormalities.

Match the glycogen storage disorders with their respective enzyme defects.

questions.solution:
Glycogen Storage Disorder Enzyme Defect Pathophysiology

Glycogen Storage Disorders (GSDs)

Glycogen storage disorders are a group of inherited metabolic diseases characterized by enzyme deficiencies affecting glycogen metabolism. These disorders cause abnormal glycogen accumulation or impaired glycogen utilization in various tissues.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for a routine check-up. During the visit, her diet is discussed, and it is noted that she has been consuming a high carbohydrate diet. You are asked to explain the impact of her dietary habits on glycogen metabolism. Which of the following statements best describes glycogen metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B)Reduced peripheral lipolysis

A high-carbohydrate diet increases blood glucose levels, leading to insulin secretion, which promotes glycogen synthesis and suppresses glycogen breakdown. The body enters the fed state, characterized by active glycogenesis and glucose utilization.

  • High glucose levels → Insulin release
  • Insulin stimulates glycogen synthase → Increased glycogen synthesis
  • Inhibits glycogen phosphorylase → Decreased glycogen breakdown.

Glycogen Metabolism in Different Metabolic States

Glycogen metabolism is regulated by the body's metabolic state, primarily influenced by insulin, glucagon, and epinephrine. The balance between glycogenesis (glycogen synthesis) and glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown) ensures glucose homeostasis.

Metabolic State Primary Hormone Glycogen Metabolism Key Enzymes Involved
Fed State (Option B ruled out) Insulin ↑ Glycogenesis, ↓ Glycogenolysis Glycogen synthase (activated), Glycogen phosphorylase (inhibited)
Fasted State (Option A ruled out) Glucagon ↑ Glycogenolysis, ↓ Glycogenesis Glycogen phosphorylase (activated), Glycogen synthase (inhibited)
Starvation State (Option C ruled out) Glucagon, Cortisol Glycogen nearly depleted, ↑ Gluconeogenesis Gluconeogenic enzymes (e.g., PEPCK, F-1,6-BPase)
Post-Exercise State (Option D ruled out) Epinephrine, Insulin (during recovery) ↑ Glycogenolysis during exercise, ↑ Glycogenesis during recovery Glycogen phosphorylase (exercise), Glycogen synthase (recovery)

Fed State and Glycogenesis (Option B ruled out)

  • After a high-carbohydrate meal, blood glucose levels increase, stimulating insulin secretion from the pancreas.
  • Insulin activates glycogen synthase, promoting the conversion of glucose into glycogen in the liver and muscle.
  • Glycogenolysis is inhibited to store excess glucose.

Fasted State and Glycogenolysis (Option A ruled out)

  • Low blood glucose stimulates glucagon release, which activates glycogen phosphorylase, breaking down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate.
  • This provides energy for vital functions, primarily in the liver to maintain blood glucose levels.

Starvation State and Gluconeogenesis (Option C ruled out)

  • Glycogen stores are depleted after prolonged fasting.
  • The body shifts to gluconeogenesis, converting amino acids and glycerol into glucose.
  • Cortisol and glucagon drive this process.

Post-Exercise State and Glycogen Replenishment (Option D ruled out)

  • After intense exercise, muscle glycogen is depleted, and the body prioritizes glycogen resynthesis.
  • Insulin sensitivity is high, allowing rapid glucose uptake for glycogenesis in muscle cells.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true on the structure of glycogen?


	Arranged in 12 concentric layers
	Glucose residues are connected by ɑ-1,4 linkage
	Branching points formed by α-1,6 linkage
questions.solution:
• A spherical molecule, approximately 21 nm in diameter, observable under electron micrographs
  • Arranged in 12 concentric layers (Statement 1)
  • The glycogenin protein is present at the center
  • Composed of polysaccharide chains, each containing approximately 13 glucose residues
  • Branched chains in the inner layers and unbranched chains in the outermost layer
  • Short chains of glucose residues are linked by α-1,4 glycosidic bonds (Statement 2)
  • Branch points are formed by α-1,6 glycosidic bonds (Statement 3)
  • Heavily branched and compact, it can store a large amount of energy in a limited space due to its compact structure

questions.text: A 25-year-old male athlete presents to the emergency department after completing a high-intensity interval training session. He reports feeling extremely fatigued and experiencing muscle cramps. Blood tests indicate elevated levels of lactic acid. What is the net ATP yield when one molecule of muscle glycogen is converted to lactic acid during strenuous exercise?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) 3 ATP

 

Explanation:

 

When one molecule of muscle glycogen undergoes anaerobic glycolysis (glycogen → lactate), the net ATP yield differs from glucose metabolism because glycogen breakdown bypasses the hexokinase step, which normally consumes ATP. Here’s a stepwise explanation:

  1. Glycogenolysis (Breakdown of Glycogen)

    • Glycogen phosphorylase removes glucose units from glycogen as glucose-1-phosphate (G1P).
    • Phosphoglucomutase converts G1P to glucose-6-phosphate (G6P).
    • Since G6P is directly obtained, it skips the hexokinase step (which normally consumes 1 ATP in glucose metabolism).

  2. Glycolysis (Conversion of Glucose-6-Phosphate to Pyruvate)

    • G6P enters glycolysis and follows the usual pathway.
    • Key ATP-related steps:
      • Energy investment: 1 ATP is used at the phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) step.
      • Energy generation: 4 ATP are produced from substrate-level phosphorylation.
      • Net ATP gain from glycolysis: 4 ATP (produced) - 1 ATP (used) = 3 ATP.

  3. Anaerobic Conditions (Conversion of Pyruvate to Lactate)

    • In anaerobic exercise (e.g., intense training), pyruvate is converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).
    • This step does not produce or consume ATP; its main role is regenerating NAD⁺ for continued glycolysis.

ATP Yield Calculation from Muscle Glycogen Breakdown

Step Process ATP Change
Glycogenolysis Glycogen → Glucose-1-phosphate → Glucose-6-phosphate (no ATP used) +0 ATP
Glycolysis Glucose-6-phosphate → 2 Pyruvate +4 ATP
Energy Consumption ATP used in glycolysis (Phosphofructokinase-1 step) -1 ATP
Anaerobic Conversion 2 Pyruvate → 2 Lactate (No ATP change) 0 ATP
Net ATP Yield   3 ATP

Final Net ATP Yield:

  • Glycolysis from muscle glycogen produces 3 ATP (instead of 2 ATP when starting from free glucose) because the hexokinase step is bypassed.
  • No additional ATP is lost or gained during lactate formation.
  • Total ATP yield per glycogen molecule → 3 ATP.

1 ATP (Option A):

  • Incorrect because the actual ATP yield is higher. Even free glucose metabolism yields 2 ATP, and muscle glycogen yields 3 ATP due to bypassing hexokinase.

2 ATP (Option B):

  • Incorrect because this is the ATP yield when glucose (not glycogen) is used. Muscle glycogen metabolism produces one extra ATP by skipping the ATP-consuming hexokinase step.

4 ATP (Option D):

  • Incorrect because glycolysis does produce 4 ATP, but 1 ATP is consumed at the PFK-1 step, leading to a net gain of 3 ATP, not 4.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates liver glycogen phosphorylase (LGP) and muscle glycogen phosphorylase (MGP)?

choices.text: LGP is activated by glucagon, while MGP is activated by epinephrine.
LGP releases glucose-6-phosphate into the bloodstream, while MGP releases free glucose into the muscle.
LGP activity is regulated by AMP, while MGP is regulated by glucagon and epinephrine.
MGP is highly active during fasting compared to LGP.

questions.solution:
Glycogen phosphorylase is an enzyme crucial for glycogen metabolism. It catalyzes the breakdown of glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate. There are two main isoforms of glycogen phosphorylase:

  1. Glycogen Phosphorylase A (Liver isoform) and
  2. Glycogen Phosphorylase B (Muscle isoform)
  • Liver Glycogen Phosphorylase (LGP) is primarily regulated by glucagon and epinephrine, which promote glycogen breakdown to maintain blood glucose levels during fasting.
  • Muscle Glycogen Phosphorylase (MGP) is activated by epinephrine and allosterically regulated by AMP, which signals low energy and promotes glycogenolysis for ATP production in muscle cells.

Aspect

Liver Glycogen Phosphorylase

(Liver-specific isoform)

Muscle Glycogen Phosphorylase

(Muscle-specific isoform)

Primary Role

 Maintains blood glucose levels by breaking down glycogen during fasting Provides glucose for ATP production during muscle contraction.

Function

Converts glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate, then to glucose-6-phosphate, which is converted to free glucose by glucose-6-phosphatase and released into the bloodstream

Converts glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate, then to glucose-6-phosphate for energy production within muscle cells (muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase)

Hormonal Activation

 Activated by glucagon (during fasting) and epinephrine (during stress) Activated by epinephrine and AMP

Allosteric Regulation

Inhibited by glucose

Activated by AMP, inhibited by ATP and glucose-6-phosphate

Response to Fasting

Increased activity

Not significantly affected

Response to Feeding

Decreased activity

Not significantly affected

Response to Exercise

No significant change

Increased activity

LGP releases glucose-6-phosphate into the bloodstream, while MGP releases free glucose into the muscle (Option B):

  • Incorrect because LGP converts glucose-1-phosphate to glucose-6-phosphate, which is then converted to free glucose by glucose-6-phosphatase and released into the bloodstream.
  • MGP does not release free glucose since muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase. Instead, glucose-6-phosphate enters glycolysis for ATP production within muscle cells.

LGP activity is regulated by AMP, while MGP is regulated by glucagon and epinephrine (Option C):

  • Incorrect because AMP primarily regulates MGP, not LGP. AMP increases MGP activity when energy levels are low.
  • LGP is regulated by glucagon and epinephrine, not AMP.

MGP is highly active during fasting compared to LGP (Option D):

  • Incorrect because LGP is highly active during fasting to maintain blood glucose levels.
  • MGP is more active during exercise, when ATP demand is high, not necessarily during fasting.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyzes the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis
questions.solution:
• Glycogen phosphorylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogenolysis. It catalyzes the phosphorolytic cleavage of α-1,4 glycosidic bonds in glycogen, releasing glucose-1-phosphate.
  • It is regulated by phosphorylation: Activated by phosphorylase kinase and inhibited by phosphoprotein phosphatase.
  • Different isoforms exist in the liver, muscle, and brain.
  • Requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme.

Glycogenolysis

Feature Details
Definition Breakdown of glycogen to release glucose
Location Primarily in liver and muscle
Purpose Provides glucose for energy during fasting (liver) and muscle contraction (muscle)
Rate-Limiting Enzyme Glycogen phosphorylase
End Products Glucose-1-phosphate (converted to glucose-6-phosphate, then to glucose in liver)

Steps of Glycogenolysis

  1. Glycogen phosphorylase:

    • Cleaves α-1,4 glycosidic bonds and releases glucose-1-phosphate.
    • Rate-limiting enzyme, activated by phosphorylation.

  2. Debranching enzyme (Glucan transferase & α-1,6-glucosidase):

    • Transfers trisaccharide units to the main chain (glucan transferase).
    • Hydrolyzes α-1,6 glycosidic bonds to release free glucose.

  3. Phosphoglucomutase:

    • Converts glucose-1-phosphate to glucose-6-phosphate.

  4. Glucose-6-phosphatase (Liver only):

    • Converts glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose, which is released into the blood.

Regulation of Glycogenolysis

Factor Effect on Glycogenolysis
Glucagon (Liver) Stimulates
Epinephrine (Muscle & Liver) Stimulates
Insulin Inhibits
AMP (Muscle) Stimulates
ATP, Glucose-6-P Inhibits
  • Glycogenolysis in muscle provides glucose-6-phosphate for glycolysis, not free glucose.
  • Glycogenolysis in liver maintains blood glucose levels during fasting.

Rate-Limiting Enzymes in Carbohydrate Metabolism

Pathway Rate-Limiting Enzyme Key Regulation
Glycolysis Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) Activated by AMP, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate; Inhibited by ATP, citrate
Gluconeogenesis Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Activated by ATP, inhibited by AMP, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate
Glycogenesis Glycogen synthase Activated by insulin, glucose-6-phosphate; Inhibited by glucagon, epinephrine
Glycogenolysis Glycogen phosphorylase Activated by glucagon, epinephrine, AMP; Inhibited by insulin, ATP, glucose-6-phosphate
Pentose Phosphate Pathway (HMP Shunt) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) Activated by NADP⁺; Inhibited by NADPH
TCA Cycle Isocitrate dehydrogenase Activated by ADP, Ca²⁺; Inhibited by ATP, NADH

These rate-limiting enzymes regulate carbohydrate metabolism by controlling the flux of substrates through their respective pathways based on energy demands and hormonal signals.

Phosphoglucomutase (Option A): Incorrect because it converts glucose-1-phosphate to glucose-6-phosphate, which is not the rate-limiting step.

Glucose-6-phosphatase (Option B): Incorrect because it converts glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose in the liver but is not involved in the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis.

Glucan transferase (Option C): Incorrect because it helps in debranching glycogen by transferring trisaccharide units but does not control the rate of glycogen breakdown.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding glycogenolysis?

choices.text: Glycogenolysis is the reverse process of glycogenesis.

questions.solution:
• Glycogenolysis and glycogenesis are distinct pathways with different enzymes and mechanisms.
  • Glycogenolysis involves breaking down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate, whereas glycogenesis involves synthesizing glycogen from glucose-1-phosphate.

Glucose-6-phosphatase acts in the liver (Option A). This enzyme functions in glycogenolysis by converting glucose-6-phosphate into free glucose, which is then released into the bloodstream.

 Glycogen phosphorylase cleaves α-1,4 linkages (Option B):

Glycogen phosphorylase cleaves α-1,4 glycosidic bonds in glycogen during glycogenolysis, releasing glucose-1-phosphate from glycogen.

 Phosphoglucomutase converts glucose-1-phosphate into glucose-6-phosphate (Option C):

Phosphoglucomutase catalyzes the reversible conversion of glucose-1-phosphate into glucose-6-phosphate.Glucose-6-phosphate can enter glycolysis for energy production or be converted into free glucose in the liver by glucose-6-phosphatase.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is activated by phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Enzymes that increase blood glucose are stimulated by phosphorylation, whereas enzymes that decrease blood glucose are stimulated by dephosphorylation.

Deactivated by phosphorylation

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase (Option A ruled out)
  • Glycogen synthase (Option B ruled out)
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase (Option C ruled out)
  • HMG-CoA reductase

Branch points occur every 8-12 glucose residues in glycogen, whereas in amylopectin, they occur every 20-30 glucose residues.
